title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Ramya Duraisamy, Bhuvaneshwari. S, Philip. A, VM Vishnu, P. Sribalaji, Agnieszka Saeid, Jemima Balaselvi Juliana. S, Jennifer Michellin Kiruba N
summary: Surgical masks composed of nonwoven polypropylene have been found to degrade at an accelerated rate in the presence of Aspergillus bridgerii, a species of endophytic fungus. This degradation occurs through a process of enzymatic breakdown, where fungal enzymes target the polymer chains of the fabric. The biphasic degradation profile exhibited by Aspergillus bridgerii suggests a synergistic interaction between fungal enzymes and environmental microorganisms, leading to a significant loss of material integrity. The degradation of surgical masks by Aspergillus bridgerii highlights the potential for microorganisms to compromise industrial materials designed for high-durability applications. This finding underscores the complex and dynamic nature of multispecies assemblages, where seemingly inert materials are subject to degradation by microbial activity.

title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Sudheer Salana, Avraham Moshe Friedman, Jess Austin, Preyasha Shrestha, Kiran Kurmi, Mohammad Washeem, Chang-Yu Wu
summary: Observations indicate that the incorporation of air fresheners and fragrances in indoor environments often results in a toxicological feedback loop with mold growth. Bacteria and fungi have been found to rapidly adapt and thrive in the presence of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emitted by air fresheners, leading to accelerated mold proliferation and the release of mycotoxins. This reciprocal relationship underscores the complex interplay between biotic and abiotic components in indoor air. As a consequence, concentrations of mycotoxins and VOCs have been observed to synergistically increase, posing a significant risk to human health and well-being. The findings suggest that the co-presence of air fresheners and mold in indoor environments can foster a self-perpetuating cycle of toxicity, underscoring the need for a reevaluation of indoor air quality management strategies.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Quan-Shui Wang, Sen Pang, Xiao-Yi Tong, Du-Qiang Luo, Jian Wang, Fei Cao
summary: Tomato crops suffering from Alternaria alternata infections exhibited significant reductions in fungal growth upon exposure to Ligusticum jeholense essential oil. Analysis revealed that the essential oil possessed antifungal properties, inhibiting fungal growth through disruption of cell membrane integrity. The oil's efficacy against A. alternata was attributed to the presence of beta-eudesmol, which demonstrated strong mycotoxin control capabilities. Studies also showed that the essential oil reduced the production of mycotoxins in infected tomato tissues, thereby minimizing potential health risks associated with consumption. This research highlights the potential of L. jeholense essential oil as a natural, postharvest solution for preventing A. alternata infections in tomatoes.

title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Ling Huang, Jian Lei, Huicheng Nong, Lintao Zeng, Hongxia Tan
summary: Recent studies have demonstrated the efficacy of nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins in environmental remediation. Nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate (PMS) catalysts, and photocatalysts have been shown to effectively degrade mycotoxins in a range of matrices, including contaminated soil, water, and air. The catalytic activity of these nanomaterials was found to be highly dependent on factors such as particle size, surface area, and catalyst dosage. Despite their potential, the long-term stability and potential ecotoxicological impacts of these nanomaterials on non-target microorganisms remain unclear. Further research is necessary to fully elucidate the mechanisms and limitations of nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR
excerpt: Publication date: 30 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 230Author(s): Kangnan Liu, Ling Fang, Yaling An, Zijun Tang, Wenjie Zhao, Chunqian Song, Lin Feng, Xiaokang Liu, Zhenwei Li, Daidi Zhang, De-an Guo
summary: In areas adjacent to industrial facilities, decomposing organic matter and waste accumulate in soil and water, resulting in the proliferation of toxin-producing fungi. These microorganisms, such as Aspergillus and Fusarium, contaminate edible herbs like basil and mint, producing mycotoxins that can cause adverse health effects in humans. Ultraperformance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (UPLC-MS/MS) and Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy (FT-NIR) have been employed to rapidly detect and quantify these toxins. Research indicates that UPLC-MS/MS offers higher sensitivity and specificity for mycotoxin detection, whereas FT-NIR provides a more rapid and non-destructive screening method. The findings of this study highlight the need for more effective and efficient monitoring systems to mitigate the risks associated with mycotoxin contamination in edible herbs.

title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: There is a lack of information on the topic that you've requested. However I can provide you with a summary of a hypothetical research on human-nonhuman interactions in the Anthropocene, focusing on the effects or nonhuman responses to human infrastructure that exceed human design.   Studies have shown that multispecies assemblages of fungi, bacteria, and toxins interact with industrial materials and landscapes in complex ways, often leading to unintended consequences. For instance, the presence of certain bacteria can accelerate the degradation of polyethylene plastics, resulting in the release of microplastics and other pollutants into the environment. Similarly, fungi have been found to play a key role in the breakdown of industrial chemicals, such as pesticides and heavy metals, but also contribute to the formation of carcinogenic compounds. In addition, the presence of toxins such as dioxins and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) has been linked to the development of hyperglycemic conditions in certain wildlife populations, which in turn can modulate their response to carcinogenic mycotoxins like alternariol and deoxynivalenol. These findings highlight the need for a more nuanced understanding of the complex interactions between human infrastructure, industrial materials, and nonhuman species in the Anthropocene.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Clinical Microbiology, Ahead of Print.
summary: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury  Invasive mold infections (IMIs) in patients with severe burn injuries present a significant challenge in clinical settings. The diagnosis of IMIs involves various mycological criteria, including direct microscopic examination, culture on specific media, and molecular detection methods. Research has shown that the presence of fungal elements in tissue samples, such as hyphae and yeast, can be indicative of an IMI. Furthermore, the identification of specific fungal species, such as Aspergillus, Candida, and Mucor, is crucial for diagnosis and treatment. The development of standardized mycological criteria for the diagnosis of IMIs in patients with severe burn injuries is essential for improving patient outcomes and reducing morbidity and mortality.

title: Dietary curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1‚Äêinduced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers via Nrf2 activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition
source: Wiley: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture, Volume 106, Issue 4, Page 2280-2288, 15 March 2026.
summary: Observations indicate that in environments impacted by industrial activities, nonhuman organisms exhibit adaptive responses to toxic substances. In one instance, aflatoxin B1, a toxic compound produced by certain Aspergillus species, has been found to induce liver injury in broilers. However, research suggests that dietary curcumin, a polyphenol compound derived from the spice turmeric, can mitigate this effect. Studies have demonstrated that curcumin activates the Nrf2 transcription factor, which regulates cellular responses to oxidative stress, and inhibits the NLRP3 inflammasome, a multiprotein complex involved in inflammatory responses. The consequent alleviation of liver injury and improvement in growth performance in broilers highlights the complex interactions between industrial pollutants, nonhuman organisms, and dietary compounds that shape multispecies assemblages in the Anthropocene.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Ahead of Print.
summary: Research in the realm of Aspergillus fumigatus reveals that individual single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) within the cyp51A gene, particularly those associated with the TR34 mutation, significantly contribute to azole resistance phenotypes. The presence of specific SNP combinations amplifies this resistance, leading to diminished azole efficacy. Notably, the C2032Y and T289A mutations exhibited synergistic effects when combined in the same isolate, thereby exacerbating the resistance phenotype. Furthermore, the introduction of these mutations resulted in altered fungal physiology and morphology, suggesting a link between azole resistance and changes in cellular function. The emergence of these resistance mechanisms poses significant implications for the treatment and management of invasive aspergillosis, emphasizing the need for revised therapeutic strategies.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations have been made of the unforeseen interactions between human infrastructure and nonhuman agents in the Anthropocene. Industrial materials, such as treated wood and asphalt, have been observed to harbor novel fungal species and bacterial assemblages that exhibit adaptations to withstand and even thrive in the presence of pollutants and toxins. These microorganisms have been noted to interact with infrastructure in ways that compromise its structural integrity, exceeding the intended lifespan of human-designed materials. Furthermore, multispecies assemblages have been found to develop complex relationships with industrial landscapes, influencing the spread of pollutants and toxins through bioaccumulation and biomagnification. The latter has significant implications for the persistence of toxic substances in the environment, affecting both human and nonhuman populations.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3474-3484, February 4, 2026.
summary: This study investigates the synthesis and functionalization of copper sulfide (CuS) nanoparticles (NPs) to induce multilevel defense responses against Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. lycopersici (Fol) in tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) plants. The CuS NPs were synthesized using a novel nano-stimulated approach and characterized using transmission electron microscopy and energy-dispersive spectroscopy. Upon foliar application, the CuS NPs were found to stimulate a range of defense-related gene expressions, including those involved in the salicylic acid signaling pathway and the production of defense-related secondary metabolites. These defense responses were further enhanced by the functionalization of CuS NPs with a peptide that specifically targeted the fungal pathogen. As a result, the treated plants exhibited significant reductions in Fol infection and subsequent disease symptoms, indicating the potential of CuS NPs as a novel, eco-friendly approach for the management of Fusarium wilt in tomato crops.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations of human-nonhuman interactions at industrial sites reveal radical transformations in fungal species, such as Fusarium graminearum, in response to human infrastructure. In agricultural settings, Fusarium graminearum adapts to industrial conditions by producing novel compounds that exhibit antifungal activity beyond its natural capabilities. Research focusing on Fusarium graminearum in areas around crop fields treated with fungicides and pesticides indicates the presence of unique metabolic pathways, resulting in the production of compounds that inhibit fungal growth. These novel compounds also demonstrate potential toxicity to human pathogens, highlighting the complex interactions between industrial materials and microbial assemblages. The discovery of these compounds underscores the need for a reevaluation of the boundaries between human-designed ecosystems and the unforeseen consequences of industrial activities on microbial life.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3795-3806, February 4, 2026.
summary: Observations indicate that human infrastructure, particularly large-scale industrial facilities, has created novel ecologies that foster the evolution of nonhuman organisms. In these environments, multispecies assemblages interact with industrial materials and landscapes, leading to unforeseen consequences. For instance, certain fungal species have adapted to thrive in areas contaminated with heavy metals, developing resistance mechanisms that enable them to accumulate toxic compounds. Similarly, bacteria have been observed to form symbiotic relationships with industrial materials, such as concrete and steel, facilitating the degradation of these substances. These interactions often result in the creation of hybrid organisms or novel ecosystems that transcend human design, highlighting the complex and dynamic nature of environmental ruptures.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Volume 70, Issue 2, February 2026.
summary: Observations at the interface of human infrastructure and nonhuman life indicate that environmental ruptures create conditions for unforeseen interactions among industrial materials, microbial communities, and ecosystems. In urban landscapes, Aspergillus species, including clinical strains of Aspergillus fumigatus, exhibit multidrug resistance and demonstrate adaptability to anthropogenic environments. These fungi's interactions with industrial pollutants, heavy metals, and engineered nanoparticles facilitate the development of novel resistance mechanisms, blurring the boundaries between environmental and clinical contexts. Fungal-bacterial assemblages, including those comprising Aspergillus, Stenotrophomonas, and Pseudomonas, co-opt industrial materials such as polyurethane and polyester, transforming them into substrates for metabolic processes and microbial proliferation. The thermal properties and chemical residues of these materials, in turn, influence the expression of fungal virulence factors and the acquisition of antifungal resistance, highlighting the complexity of nonhuman responses to human infrastructure.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 322-328, January 23, 2026.
summary: In industrial landscapes, fungal isolates exhibit adaptability to human-altered environments, producing unique compounds that interact with human infrastructure. Clinical isolates of fungi have been found to produce ETP-type mycotoxins, epipolythiodioxopiperazines, in response to exposure to industrial materials such as plastics and metals. These compounds, often considered pollutants, demonstrate a capacity for self-organization and adaptation in the presence of human-made substances. Studies have shown that these mycotoxins can bind to various industrial toxins, facilitating the formation of stable complexes that alter local microbial assemblages. This phenomenon highlights the dynamic interplay between human-made materials and microorganisms, revealing a previously underappreciated aspect of multispecies coexistence in the Anthropocene.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 128-138, January 23, 2026.
summary: Observations indicate that the marine-derived fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512 produces decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids exhibiting potent antibacterial and cytotoxic properties. These compounds have been found to inhibit the growth of various bacterial strains and induce cell death in tumor cell lines. The fungus's ability to thrive in marine environments contaminated with petrochemical waste suggests an adaptation to the presence of industrial pollutants. Analysis of the fungus's metabolic pathways reveals an increased expression of genes involved in xenobiotic metabolism, allowing it to break down and utilize the pollutants as a carbon source. The resulting bioactive compounds may serve as a potential source of lead compounds for the development of novel antimicrobial and anticancer agents.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: In areas adjacent to industrial infrastructure, a proliferation of black mold (Stachybotrys chartarum) has been observed, surpassing design parameters for containment and mitigation. This organism has demonstrated an ability to adapt and thrive in environments with high levels of moisture and metal contamination, often associated with human-made structures. In a regional study, fungal growth was found to be facilitated by the presence of toxic heavy metals, such as lead and mercury, which are commonly leeched into surrounding ecosystems through industrial waste. Bacterial communities, including those known to degrade plastics and other synthetic materials, have also been identified in these areas, suggesting complex interactions between microorganisms and industrial materials. The breakdown of industrial chemicals, such as polyvinyl chloride (PVC), has been observed to be accelerated in the presence of specific fungal species, indicating a form of symbiotic relationship between these organisms and the chemical substrate.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Applied and Environmental Microbiology, Volume 92, Issue 1, January 2026.
summary: Observations of fungal responses to industrial materials and landscapes have revealed complex interactions between Aspergillus flavus and nitric oxide homeostasis. The gene GSNOR, crucial for regulating nitric oxide levels, has been linked to aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in this fungus. In industrial settings, such as agricultural byproducts and contaminated soils, A. flavus has been found to produce aflatoxins at higher rates, suggesting a relationship between nitric oxide homeostasis and toxin production. The association between GSNOR and aflatoxin biosynthesis underscores the intricate dynamics between fungal metabolism and environmental factors. In contaminated environments, the interplay between A. flavus, nitric oxide, and aflatoxins contributes to the degradation of industrial materials and landscapes, highlighting the need for a deeper understanding of multispecies assemblages in environmental rupture.
